ygData.subject: RE: Creating Magical Armor and Weapons
ygData.msgSnippet: But in EQ you CAN be a Master Fisher, Tailor, Blacksmith, Fletcher, Jewler and Baker with enough time and money. The argument is that Enchanters can Master
ygData.messageBody:
But in EQ you CAN be a Master Fisher, Tailor, Blacksmith, Fletcher, Jewler
and Baker with enough time and money. The argument is that Enchanters can
Master Jeweling better than any other class, and that gives them an edge on
the market. Also, their high intelligence gives them the advantage of
learning the other trade skills quickly. This combination yields a very
deadly merchant who can clean up an entire zone. I know of one Enchanter on
Tunare who, within a matter of minutes of logging on, has about 50 tells for
his goods and services.
The only thing that we non-Enchanters can do is learn multiple trades so
that we can market ourselves better. I do agree with you that we should
befriend these Enchanters. It can only help us.

> Well, as a smith, you expect people to pay you for your time and skill,
> correct?
>
> That being the case, why should you not pay an enchanter for his time and
> services?
>
> Why should a master fisherman be able to make armor? Why should a master
> talor be able to cook a complicated pie? They shouldn't. Certainly
> enchanters have an advantage when it comes to making magic items, but then
> again, shouldn't an enchanter have an advantage since their whole class is
> based upon enchantments? And if you people are afraid that the day will
> come that you can't make magic armor because some enchanter is doing it,
> you are wrong. You will still be able to, you might have to pay an
> enchanter to enchant some items for you, but you will still be able to
> make it. And if you strongly feel that they will alow smiths to make
> magic armor, perhaps you should do a little adventuring and find some
> enchanters to become buddies with, perhaps he will do it for a nominal
> fee, or perhaps even free.
>
